This collection contains a 1940 report: Report on Investigations Concerning the Future Development of the School of Architecture and Allied Arts by a Committee of Faculty of the School. This report was created to survey the value of the School of Architecture and Allied Arts to New York University and the community.

The School of Architecture and Allied Arts was established as a department of architecture in 1926 under the leadership of architect E. Raymond Bossange. Two years later, the University established a College of Fine Arts (which the department of architecture was a part of) and elevated Bossange to its deanship in 1930. In 1935, the College was renamed the School of Architecture and Allied Arts. The School was closed in 1941.
"N.Y.U. Will Close Architects' School," New York Times, May 18, 1941 (accessed February 9, 2023).

Material transferred from the New York University Archives Collection of Publications and Ephemera (MC 334) during processing in 2022; there is no documentation concerning the provenance of these materials.
